fact: Malaria is caused by a Plasmodium parasite transmitted through mosquito bites.
More than 400,000 people die of malaria every year.
Children under 5 are the most vulnerable group affected by malaria.
Malaria is preventable and curable with timely treatment.
Africa carries 94% of the world's malaria cases and deaths.
Insecticide-treated bed nets are a major preventive tool against malaria.
There are 5 types of malaria parasites that infect humans.
Plasmodium falciparum is the most deadly malaria parasite.
The World Health Organization recommends artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) to treat malaria.
Malaria symptoms include fever, headache, and chills, appearing 10â€“15 days after a mosquito bite.
The RTS,S/AS01 (Mosquirix) malaria vaccine is the first malaria vaccine recommended by WHO.
Pregnant women are at higher risk of severe malaria and complications.
Malaria can be diagnosed using Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) or microscopy.
Indoor residual spraying is another malaria prevention method.
Climate change and environmental conditions impact mosquito breeding and malaria transmission.
